[[pencil note in top margin:  Knepler, Henry  [no date] ]]
Dear Mr. Conroy--
Your delightful book with its charming dedication is lying on my desk, and I have taken a fancy to picking it up and reading a selection here and there. Many thanks!
Henry Knepler

printed letterhead  memoranda:
6/24/73
Dear Jack--
No time to write but I wanted you to have this. I could think of no one who would appreciate it more.
Marion?

a check (25 ₵ a print), I never got it.
Would you believe that it took until a couple of weeks ago for the originals to get back to me?
Marion?

handwritten note  Project pictures

Dear Jack and Gladys,
I'm still sending out my New Year's cards--so please don't think you've been singled out for neglect. The enclosed letter may explain the long delay. M
File:Peace in several languages: PEACE * PAIX * PAZ * MИP * ?  and happiness in '75

Marion Spencer Franc

pencil note in top margin  Knoblauch-Franc, Marion  [1976]
A toast to your well-being in 1977
Dear Jack and Gladys.

   It was good to get Jack's usual holiday note, but sad to hear about Margaret Jean.  I know how those six months of hospital vigil must have drained you.  Life can be terribly cruel.
  1976 was the year I was going to write some articles using the research I did no Chicago historical sites for the Commission on Chicago Landmarks, but now it's 1977 and I still haven't done them.   I'm discouraged about myself.  I did, however, have an exciting two weeks in Japan and Hong Kong as a fringe benefit to a part-time job I've had with an international health organization since last March.

card with picture "Evening World" by Momodou Ceesay, Gambia.  Design contributed to benefit UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund.
Now, of course, I'd like to do an article based on the notes I made on that trip.   But so far I've let everyday chores and socializing take precedence.   The old story.

  I see Olga frequently and she is always interested in news of you.   She's been in the East visiting son Bruce and his family and is due back soon.  I know she'll be sad about your daughter.
  I shall try to get the underlined:  December issue with your chapter, Jack.

Love, Marion

in pencil in top margin:  Knoblauch-Franc, Marion
letterhead  Marion Knoblauch Franc  5040 Marine Drive   Chicago, Illinois  60640
19 January 1977
[in red pencil between date and salutation:  (I wrote this before talking with you.) ]]
Dear Jack:  
Thanks for your recent letter alerting me to a possible visit from the "feller" who called you from New York about a documentary on the Writers' Project.  There are two men involved, and they were here for three hours yesterday afternoon, along with a TV crew of three.  The names of the two are Olaf Hansen and Wieland Schulz-Keil.  Olaf teaches American Studies at Frankfurt University but is spending a year at Harvard.  The documentary is already sold to West German TV and possibly may be sold to TV in the US, if they are lucky.  It is not just on  the Writers' Project but on all the cultural Projects and the New Deal in general, I believe.  They interviewed Studs, of course, and MacDougall, and Nate, and me.  Olga Davidson was here when they did me, and they talked with her but did not "do" her.  They were interested in the"scandals " both of my Project books caused--not for their sensational value but as an inquiry into why these Government publications got into trouble.  a strange sidelight:  while I gathered that Curtis D. is still apoplectic about me and the favorable light Jerre's book put me into, as opposed to the way MacD. handled the civil liberties book episode, he gave them the impression that he was rather proud of the book! ? !

 The crew has gone on its way, to see people in Madison and Minnesota and then, I think, they'll be heading your way.  crossed out:  They forgot this nice appointment book, so I'm sending it to you to return to them.  handwritten note in left margin:  Please ask them where I should send it.  I think you'll enjoy talking with them.  They know a lot.
 Some people are beginning to wonder whether you could be a closet writer of some of those religious tracts you distribute with your correspondence.  Tell me it isn't so!
 I not only saw Jim Phelan on Kup's Show Sunday night, but he treated Olga, Nate, and me to an elegant brunch at the Continental Plaza earlier that day.  He was in town to tape numerous shows, and is making the PR rounds all over the country.  He's also making underlined:  scads of money.

Love,   Marion
P.S. Please also give Olaf & Wieland the enclosed.
File:Postcard photo of high-rise building with fountain in front

Post Card
[[pencil notation in upper right corner:  Knoblauch-Franc, Marion  [1977]
4/14/77
arrow pointing to  IMPERIAL HOTEL TOKYO CORRESPONDENCE  (this is where I was last November.  A far cry from Frank Lloyd Wright)
Dear Jack:

 A note from Wieland Schulz-Keil in answer to the note I had written 3/10 says he went to Europe after the trip through the U.S. to talk with some Theatre Project people who are now in European theatres.  He now plans 3-4 months of editing of the film.  Did you give him that note I sent in care of you?  He made no mention of it.  He also said he'd let me know the broadcasting dates in this country.   I didn't know the film had been sold.  More anon.

Love, Marion
Mr Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, MO
65270
IMAGE on card of two birds in a frame

Post Card
Postmark:  CHICAGO IL 
pencil notation in top margin of post card Knoblauch-Franc, Marion
Ducks - Canards   Mosaid, III century A.D.  Musee national du Bardo, Tunis, Tunisia    To benefit UNICEF

 I didn't hear from you this holiday season, so I hope all is well with you.  I'm just doing my New Year notes, and I wish you the best.
 I'm anxious to see Schulz-Keil's films of the Arts Projects.  Think I'll send for a video-cassette.  Have you seen any of them?
 I read & enjoyed your "Morphadite" chapter.  How goes the book?

Marion
Mr & Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, MO
65270

Notecard with pencil notation above date:  Knoblauch-Franc, Marion

Dear Jack,

  Congratulations!  Wish I could be there, but I'm still caught up in my work on the Federal Music Project  history.  Julius Echeles wanted to come, too, but he  has to be in court that day.
  I'm sorry to miss seeing

You - and also Doug Mixson and Stephen Wade, whose show I loved a few yeas ago.

Marion Knoblauch-Franc

TWO POSTMARKS  SPRINGFIELD IL 627  CHICAGO   1987
Dear Jack,

  I miss your former holiday notes and religious tracts, but I know you're still alive and writing because I recently read your review of the biography of Ben Reitman.  Anyhow, all the best to you.  How you must be enjoying the depths to which the Reagan Administration has fallen!  

Marion Knoblauch Franc

Mr. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, MO
65270

Dear Jack:  This may not look like one, but it is a New Year's card to send you my best wishes for you in '89.  God, did you ever think we'd make it this far, despite wars and plagues like the Reagan administration?!  Do you think Bush's machinations will come to light during his term?  I strongly hope so, but then we'll have Quayle!  Fondly, Marion
printed label  Marion Knoblauch-Franc  5040 N Marine Dr = 1-A  Chicago, IL  60640
Mr. Jack Conroy crossed out:  1801 Towne Dr. Columbia, MO 65202
Underlined:  Forward
Moberly Caring Ctr.
Moberly, MO  65270

13251 Lingne Ave
Poway, Calif  92064
Sept 22, 1974
Dear Mr. Conroy.

  At the present time I am a student of Mrs. Mony Redding at San Diego Stat [sic] Un., working on my master's degree in English.  This is my second class with Dr. Redding and in both classes we have read your book underlined:  The Disinherited, which, I would like to add, I enjoyed very much.  Now I would like to do an additional paper on you and your book for the Proletarian Literature class.  Also if it is agreeable to you Dr. Redding thought I could write to you, giving you some of the views of the class and asking questions that I might need for my paper.  
  At the present time I would truly like to see more Proletarian Lit. taught in the High schools and maybe even the Jr Highs.  I feel it is a much suppressed form of literature in our schools with no other way for our children to understand the working conditions and social events of their grandfathers and great grandfathers.  My own 15 year old son reads my books and finds them both important and enjoyable.

While working on your paper and asking you questions I would also like to ask you a few about Richard Wright's underlined:  Native Son if I may.   Your views on him would be very greatly appreciated as I have a critical study to do of the history of the criticism of his book.
  Before I close my letter I would like to say I'm sorry for my poor handwriting, my typewriter is being repaired and I could wait no longer to write to you.  Maybe I should also add a few things about myself.  I am 37 years old, have a husband and four children and feel as if I have been going to school forever.  Though we live in Southern Calif now, my home is in upper Washington state, my father being a logger most of his life.  I do hope someday someone will write a good proletarian book about the logging trade and the men involved in it.  It is a very colorful life and should be told before all the trees are gone and the work is a thing of the past.
  I hope to hear from you, knowing the large amount of writing you do to so many people I would like to thank you for your time.

Always - Jan Knodle

That sincerely is with great appreciation.  Your letter is probably the nicest thing which has happened to me all semester.
Jan Knodle

Nov. 25 1974
13251 Lengne Ave
Poway Calif  92064
Dear Mr. Conroy,

  I received the magazines and then passed them on to Mary Redding.  She is making her copies and said she would return them to you with a letter.  I would like to send back this clip before I lose it and also some copies of it I had made so you will have some to mail to other students, saving your own copy fro forgetful people like myself.  Mrs. Redding has her copy too.  Thank you for all the material and time and money sending it out here.  Also for your comment on the American Communists and where I could read more on it, that was another question.
  After reading Dr. Fried's "The Worker as Writer" I have decided I like his answer to where you might have gone at the end of underlined:  The Disinherited.  At one time I felt you might have taken part in some move with the unions, but his answer was much better.  Could I ask about the character Hons though?
  I have also read your "Robert Cantwell's underlined: Land of Plenty and a now trying to find a book store here which has the novel.  My hometown is Hoquiam, Washington, in fact my

mother

still lives there and worked at the plywood factory during the second World War.  There were several plants then, most of them closed in the late '40's or '50's.  My father worked for a short time in the plants until he begin logging in the very late 40's.  My children went to school in Aberdeen and my sister taught there until this past summer.   As we are going home at Christmas, to be with my mother, I would like to begin a little research about Cantwell and the factory he worked in.  Is there any ideas you could give me (your helpful hints are so very good).  I still have a very good friend teaching American Lit at Grays Harbor Jr College and hope to enlist his help if I don't get everything done this trip.  I know my mother will think it a great idea, as maybe I will be able to go home again and finish my research.  The lynching in Centralia is indicative of the people who live around Grays Harbor, they are ultra everything and once they take a stand, one side or the other, you are unable to change them.  I also think the weather has a lot to do with the character of the people.

   I'm sorry this letter was ment [sic] to be a short note and I got carried away.  Once again

Sincerely
Jan Knodle

-2-
carpenters.  I must be, for my boss voluntarily strengthened our tie by giving me a quarter an hour raise - above scale.  I value my carpentry mainly because it keeps me in superb physical condition and in good appetite.  On the other hand, I am saddened to be helping reproduce a lousy situation generally.  Engels sure said it when he wrote his thesis on The Housing Question, way back in the 19th century.

  I will end with a little story which illustrates how Chucky never lets illness dehumanize her.  Recently I visisted [sic] her after work at St. Joseph Hospital.  It was plain she had been crying.  "You hurt that much?" I asked.
  "Of course," she replied, "but that's not why I cried.  It's something that happened down in therapy."
  It seems she had been sitting in a wheel chair, between two other patients in wheel chairs, waiting for their treatments.  On her left was a charming old Negro man who said he had spent his whole life being "boy" to the famous Jock Whitney in connection with his string of racing horses.  He had thus traveled in  high class circles and seen most of the world, picking up knowledge of the world and its peoples.  He had occasion to whisper to Chucky, later, "You sure told it like it was . . . and is."
  Turning from the old man, Chucky had attempted to initiate a conversation with the woman on her right.  Somehow they got to discussing the problems of the inner cities, the slums and ghettos.  The woman volunteered that if she could have her way the program of Aid to Dependent Children would be ended, thus stopping all those women from having so many illegitimate children so they could get the checks.  Chucky countered with some history, going back to slavery to point out how we had enslaved the blacks, raped their women, separating families by selling husbands and wives to separate owners.  She pointe out how we create the dependency which forces the present day breakup of the Negro family.  By this time the woman had haughtily rolled her wheel-chair a few feet forward.  Chucky pursued to apologize, "I'm sorry if I've been a bit sharp with you, personally."
  "Don't you know it's all spelled out in detail in the bible?" the woman explained.  "We are only doing the Lord's work when we make it hard on the black people."  She went on to say something to the effect that when Cain slew Abel the Lord was so mad he punished Ham and his descendants by making them black.  And they were to be punished the rest of their days.  Chucky is no scholar of the bible so she couldn't discuss the fine points of that.
 Chucky sat mute for a minute or two, then asked, "By the way, what do you do?"  "I don't work," the woman replied, then added, "But I am a member of the School Board."
 "I found myself crying," Chucky told me.  "The tears just poured down my face.   What more could I say?  What more could I do?  I don't suppose she is a member of the School Board of Chicago, but she is surely on the school board of a suburb.  That was when the old man leaned toward me to say, 'You sure told it like it is.'"
 Even though our greetings are belated, rest assured we value and cherish you all more than ever this year, and we rejoice that there are still human decency and strength and courage in the world to keep the fires burning. 

As always our love,
Chucky and Ray
Koch
451 W. Aldine
Chicago, Illinois  60657
handwritten upside down in bottom margin    It's nice to have you remember us down Missouri way.  Do they still make fire bricks down there?  Read all your reviews and enjoy their substance.  Ray

postcard
postmark  CHICAGO, ILL PM 25 MAR 1980
3-24-80
Dear Jack & Gladys

 The best laid plans etc... My niece (in Columbia) and 2 of her 3 children have flu so our trip is off for now.  We are disappointed, too, about not seeing you.  I understand Steve Wade was entranced with you.  Maybe we'll be able to do the trip this summer.  Stay well - Affectionately Chucky & Ray

Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Mo.
65270

[in pencil in top margin] Koch, Ray
3-6-80
Dear Jack

 We plan to be in Columbia March 27-28 and will be leaving there early Sat. a.m. and could head up through Moberly & have breakfast with you someplace.  If you're going to be home send us your phone no. if it is not still 816/263-3268.
  Message can be left in Columbia with our niece Cheryl Guthrie at 314/442-5038.
  Glad to see your book is getting such great reviews and attention.  Hope it also results in many royalty checks -

Affectionately Chucky & Ray
[in left margin:]  1116 W North Shore Ave. Chicago, Ill  60626

envelope
RAY & CHARLOTTE KOCH
1116 W NORTH SHORE AV
CHICAGO, IL  60626
Postmark  CHICAGO IL 606 PM 27 DEC  1988
Jack Conroy 
℅ P. Hazlet
212 Crest Dr.
Moberly, Mo.  65270
Ans. 1-4-89

pencil note in top margin  Koch, Ray and Chucky

July 17, 1986
Dear Doug (copy to Jack) or Dar Jack (copy to Doug)
Got both your letters.  This is a little hurry note just to say we've had trouble finding another copy of the book.   We want to take one to a friend in Shanghai who is teaching English there.  Can you tell me a book store here who is surely handling it?  If not could one of you get me a copy in time.  We leave September 3rd.  Maybe autographed!!!  (I'm talking about WEED KING of course.

  My brother spent another week with us - left Tuesday to go home to St. Joseph, Mo.  It's in the bone marrow now (cancer) and he's offered no more hope.  Goes down visibly by the day.  So it's been a rather traumatic time for me.
  Y'all can expect the annual letter in late October - this one on China.

Affectionately, Chucky
handwritten note at end of letter  Jack - "Interesting" is the one word I would never use in reference to Weed King.  1st:  It's a cop-out word meaning nothing.  the kind every scribbler shuns.  2nd - The Weed King is in the highest class of writing.  Down with "Interesting!"  Ray

postcard
B.K.
NINOL LABORATORIES = Manufacturing Chemists  1719 SOUTH CLINTON STREET  CHICAGO 16, ILLINOIS      Ninoletter

With many thanks for making the passing year a brighter one.    Ben Kirk

letterhead
William Kruck  411 Eklund Avenue   Geneva, Illinois  60134  Phone 312-232-2948

July 29
Jack dear!

  Thank you so much for the review and your great letter - have been vacationing therefore delay - no, we are not free to go travelling - Red can't get free as yet, but soon we hope - liberation will be sweet!  And Moberly Missouri is a must.
  Watching the House Judiciary Committee in action and quite wonderful, almost unbelievable -
  Hope to see you both soon

and love,
Red and Paula

Pencil in top margin  Kruck, Tom, ca Jan 1985

Dear Jack, 
Red had a heart attack while on vacation in Poncé, Peurto [sic] Rico.  I am here now to be with him while he recovers.  I will be here for three or four weeks.   Red will be recovered in a month or so.  His life will continue.  He will live because he is macho gringo.
Love, Tom

[IMAGE:  pen sketches on a piece of notebook paper showing facing heads]
JACK CONROY:  HOW HE THINKS HE LOOKS -
JACK CONROY:  HOW HE REALLY LOOKS -

in pencil in top margin  Lacey, Patricia

4834 N. Damen Avenue
Chicago 25, Illinois
November 26, 1955
Dear Mr. Conroy,

 Thank you for your careful and kindly criticism of my poems.  I am so familiar with them that it is difficult to be objective.  You have given me quite a lot to think about.  I realize with a shock that if some of them are "obtrusively stereotyped," this could very well be because I also am!
  Emily Dickinson used to be a favorite of mine; so you say,

she had the genius for making simplicity or even "cliché" distinctive.  That gives me much to work towards, I agree.  However, as to whether a poet should create according to his own rules, I believe he should first learn the rules of the master craftsmen before he makes his own.

  I am glad you think some of the verses are worth sending to the magazines you suggested.  This I shall do, hoping I select the right ones.
  Please know that I value and appreciate the trouble or effort involved in your criticism.  You are quite a writer yourself.

Sincerely,
Patricia Lacey

December   19 -
4049 W. Wrightwood
Chgo. Ill 60639
(New address)
Dear Jack Conroy,

    I betcha Jackie Susann really longs to write the book, for all her exploitation of a willing  public.  Perhaps your lectures will plough up future Jackie Susanns and broaden their scope.  It is really not her writing that bothers me, for I do not have to read it.  It is her money for the writing that keeps one awake nights.
   Possibly Jackie really has "good taste," to quote another Jackie, but that is not what the public wants, nor does the public want art.
   But I love this Country where all these "Jackies" can be heard - and along these lines, your book "The Disinherited"

would make a good movie - just enough time has passed and changes occurred to make the 30's historic - look how well "Bonnie & Clyde" did (the movie I mean.)  You are a different "Jackie", and People are still looking for answers.

   In the meantime I am quietly writing famous poems which I disdain to sell even though no one wants to buy them.   It is a proper and lady-like occupation, and certainly sustains my ego --

Sincerely,
Patricia Lacey

December  14, 1968
Dear Mr. Conroy,

  The enclosed correspondence wraps up my venture into publication for 1968.  Mr. Westberg enclosed an extra copy of the fall issue of Mentor which I am enclosing so that you can see it has now shrunk to 22 pages.   I made a copy of your Chicagoland article and forwarded it to Mr. Westberg thinking it would be of interest to him; also sent him a thank you note for his elaborate reply to my letter.
  We enjoyed underlined:  very much your book "The Disinherited."  Dialect is often difficult to bear with in reading, yet yours seemed natural and

by the middle of the story, I rode past my station on the way to work reading it one morning.  underlined:  That is a good book.  The detailed descriptions of methods, processes etc. involved in manufacture, and other phases of your story, give it a careful, thorough character of very real interest.  You do reach out and grab the reader; my daughter says this is called "instant rapport".  The episodes dealing with the strikes fill in for me what were merely headlines once, as I was a child during the Depression years, and knew it's [sic] other equally devastating aspects.  Son, Dave, found the book rich with the lore of those years and the particular problems of your particular characters confined in the strictures of the times.  Still, the recent mine disaster and subsequent report makes you wonder if

that aspect has seen much improvement, really.

 I wonder if to cover the depression years one would not find himself eventually crawling through some kind of maze.   The War, "technocracy", the Atomic Age, Professor Keynes, the invention of plastics, the popularity of Liberalism, the Pill, the "new" morality, TV, the giant packaging industry, outer space travel, the recent surge of the black race to attain their Constitutional rights, Korea, Viet Nam, - somewhere back in those other years there lay the seeds of these enormous events!  As you seemed to say, there was more than one pot boiling.  A cousin of mine published a history of the northwest, and in there had a section on the banking business in those days, and 

in left margin    The Land of the Dakotahs by Bruce Nelson

touched on strikes as well.  Maybe a sleeping giant was stirring.  Yet it seems now strikes have come to be not the servant but the master of us; economically we escalate, yet the GNP increases  yearly, so apparently no (real) harm is done.   This about encompasses my "economic" philosophy garnered from God Knows Where - I just keep underlined:  trying to understand the situation!   Such mental indigestion!

  Am enclosing also a clipping from Sun Times which has a mention of your name, no doubt you have seen this already.
  I don't know how these things work, but I wonder why I had to order your book, - it seems it would be a good seller if put out on the stands.  Krocks V Bretano's [sic] took 5 weeks to get it for me.  That is the La Salle Street store.  Perhaps the Wabash Avenue store is better stocked.  I shall research this factor for you.

Sincerely
Patricia Lacey

3056 Montrose Avenue
Chicago 18, Illinois
September 11, 1967
Dear Mr. Conroy,

    Ever since you were kind enough to look over some of my poems and render helpful suggestions several years ago, I have been a "fan" of yours.   That is, I have followed your reviews in the Book Week section of the Sunday Sun Times, in which there was often better writing to be found than in some of the books reviewed.
  Now I am wondering why you are not mentioned in the list of reviewers presented last Sunday as coming up in the new Book Week section.   This may be none of my business, yet since you have

unwittingly become a friend of mine, I am presuming to ask where I can, in the future, expect to read your reviews.  I am not even sure you appeared in the last issues last year.
Sincerely,
Patricia Lacey

Robin Lampson,
1116 Thorne Ave., 
Fresno, Calif.
Nov. 25, 1929
Hugh Hanley,
224 W. Pacemont Road,
Columbus, Ohio.
Dear Mr. Hanley:

   Florence Keene of underlined:  Westward has forwarded to me your kind letter of Nov. 13th addressed to her.   I want to thank you for your"kind words" about underlined:  Shell-Shock.
  I would like to know more about "Rebel Poets" and trust you will send information, sample copy of publication, etc.
  I have written much verse in rebellion against the underlined:  status quo, but have never been very avid for publication.  I became interested in Russia in 1918, began studying Russian, spent the year 1922 in Russia with the famine relief, and have translated a number of Russia's classic lyrics (one slated to appear in next issue of underlined:  Westward.). . . Just today I submitted a s[?hort?] story paper torn at bottom of page in verse, about Russia, to underlined:  The Forum - but torn paper be able to stand the shock if they a torn paper

Cordially yours
torn paper mpson

Barrytown 12507
May 6th
Dear Jack

  We will be delighted to see  you on or about May 18th for as long as your wish to stay.
   We live about 20 miles directly North of where FDR is planted.  Croton is about 65 miles SE.  By car it is on the taconic [sic] Parkway to Lafyetteville where highway 199 crosses it and then about ten miles directly West to where it crosses #9-G.  Continue due West at this point for abut 1/3 of a mile.   The schollhouse [sic] is obvious before you reach the fork in the road.
  Railroads these days you know dislike passengers but they do stop at harmon (Croton on Hudson) and once or twice a day at Rhinecliff nearby also Poughkeepsie   The railroad prohibits the use of buses on this side of the river but operate infrequently between Poughkeepsie and nearby Red Hook.   Everybody but us owns two or three cars as you know and that makes transportation difficult and dangerous.
   However Lu's brother is paying us a visit a week from now and we are renting a car so that we can ick you up here or there when we know when or where -- perhaps Hyde Park.  Or Rhinebeck or Poughkeepsie.
   Our telephone Area 914 (same as Croton)  PLateau 8 5178 and we are usually home 24 hours a day.  Because mail is somewhat uncertain I am sending a carbon of this to New York.   The mailman will be passing by soon and I must get dressed to get this posted so must get this posted right away.  We can talk other business over when we meet.  It will be grand seeing you both.  It's been a helluva long time
   Barrytown is somewhat an undersized Woodstock with Gore Vidal and Mary Lee Settle (3 guggenheims) for nearby neighbors.  St Josephs Christiam [sic] Brothers are across the street and Bard College near them.

More power to you
The Surde
F. V. Lamson

Baltimore Md  June  2nd
Dear Jackson

   I think I know what you mean about killing snakes.  I've been so damn busy I haven't even been able to use the phone for an easy way to avoid writing.  The wedding was an overwhelming success in every way and I am living in a new world all dimmed out with a stardust fog.  But I did get a helluva lot done before coming here a little more than 24hours  

ago.  I will stay here as much as I can and almost all of the time until Lu is able to come with me probably before the end of the year.

   We live less than two blocks N E of the old Washington monument that is the center of the city.  Very easy to find when and if you are passing by.  The phone number is VErnon 7 2489.  Yesterday I lunched in the Sage of Baltimore's favorite stube on knockwurst, sauerkraut and Pabst, whic [sic] had been brewed I believe in poluted [sic] hudson River water.  It had all kinds of atmosphere in the famous 2nd hand book shop but unless I can get Millers Highlife, Blatz or some true Milwaukkee [sic] or imported beer, I probably won't go back.
   Glad you are going back over my Oregon Trail as well as so many other places.  And that you are grinding things out again.  When and if I can get things going the way they should I may take a whirl at helping support the family with my typewriter.
   Since there are dozens of other letters 1/2iled [sic] at my side, I am going to make this brief as you may not see it for weeks anyway.  Hope you can drop in here or there sometime before very long.  Barrytown is becoming a colony like Woodstock.  Mary Lee Settle is a new neighbor two doors away -- a couple young Bard students will be my nearest neighbors after buying the Oaks for some 50 "G's"  And there are any number of new professors, artists etc moving in nearby.
  Elizabeth is E. Louise like I am F.Vernon but she is like winning the Sweepstakes.  I am sure you three will enjoy each other.

May we all live foreve [sic] and enjoy doing it
The Surde
Many thanks for all of the interesting enclosures

Dear Jack "guggenheim" Conroy

  Too damn bad I missed you.  I haven't forgotten you by any means and if I looked under my blotter I'd probably find 4 or 6 letters that I started and never finished.  I've gotten reports on you from various emissaries including Jean Hough and that screwball  you sent my way about 5 years ago and others.
  I've been wondering what the hell you were doing after completing that monumental mail order encyclopedia but I never expected you to showup in the flesh pots at Saratoga - is it women, horses or gambling?
  I can't steal too much time for this letter so I will have to talk fast.  I'd dearly love to spend sometime with you before you disappear again.
  Mary and I busted up about four years ago and I managed to salvage very little of the fruits of my 25 years labor in this dung pit.  But I do own the title  on what was once a schoolhouse in Barrytown NY near Red Hook.  About ½ mile from the RR station.  It's going to be quite a place and it almost is now.
  I'd like to have you hole up there as long as you can.  The key is at the neighbors next door, a gal by the name of Chamberlain and you can make yourself to home until I show up.
  My plans for the next month are a bit confused at the moment.  Sept 1st I go to a crypt convention in R.I. and should show up in Barrytown for a couple days about Sept 6th and thence perhaps to Indiana until about the 16th.
  I also maintain a one room apartment at 338 East 53rd St in Manhattan.  The telephone is Eldorado 5 0278 and if you had looked a little closer at the phone book you would have found me listed under my own moniker.
  Let's see if we can't get together for an old fashioned  visit.  The only times I've seen you in the last 25 yers I've had to compete with the entire communist party and I would like to get thoroughly reacquainted.

Salute
Ye Surde
handwritten note in left margin  I am damn seldom there except between the hours of 1 AM and 8 AM Sundays to Fridays.

letterhead
F. VERNON LAMSON  4317 CAROLIN STREET   SUNNYSIDE, LONG ISLAND CITY
March 17 1931
Dear Jack

   I've intended to answer your letter long ago but the thriving utility I work for just opened up and gave me a raise and now they are naturally asking for more than heretofore.  They'll get it for a while.
   I chanced upon the Masses that didn't like Unrest.  I got a laugh - of course you know they are right no damn half-dizzy, half starved poet is going to ever wiggle the structure - neither is any mangy Union Square Communist   Our crazy system is either going to grow up and bust or putrefy of its own accord without any help from anybody.
   My old man is partly right at that.  I have changed.  With a job that requires no mentality or ability - in fact where what I have oft times proves a severe handicap - with everything I need

in the way of creature comforts in a modest way - a nice home, good food, good liquor, its hard to get excited about anything or be anything else than smug, happy and contented.

   I still have all of my fundemental [sic] beliefs and hates.  I see life from an entirely new perspective.  I see the stupidity the mad disordered blundering of the people who run the works.  By that I mean the dinners conferences, conventions, sales campaigns, and other fol de roll that causes factories to run.  It's insane the whole damn business and some day probably soon everything's going to pot  I dont like it but its too big for poor little me to fight.  I am gawd damn glad to string along and stay well fed and contented.
  I'd like to live under some sort of a Socialist state.  I dont ever expect to though.  I am tremendously interested in Russia and where she is going.  There at the present time I

letterhead  F. VERNON LAMSON  4317 CAROLIN STREET  SUNNYSIDE, LONG ISLAND CITY
believe something is happening that will disturb the world more than the birth of a dozen Christs.  I believe in Socialism of some sort -- it is a rational and inteligent [sic] basis of living - but I have no ilusions [sic] in regard to its chances for success.  I vote for socialists partly because I like a few of them but mostly because its the only chance I have to say that I dont like things as they are a damn bit.

   Some day perhaps my company will get nasty and fire me - when they do Id like to sit down and write a novel that would burn the pants off 'em.   This may happen but it doesnt seem very likely.
  If I were as  broke or hungry as I was seven years ago now I'd be a much different person than I was before I know

but I hope I never am.

  Every week or so I read your Hard Winter and it does things to me   It drives home the ugly fact that there is an altogether different world than the one I am living in and that is disturbing    I hope H.L. hurries up with  your next article.  Also that you land with Scripps Howard or sell enough to the Mercury and others to give you what is honestly yours.  I further hope that you never get as smug or lazy as I am.
  I do hope to see you in New York ere long.  There are lots of things to do and see.  We live in a very interesting and civilized semi surburban [sic] community called Sunnyside with a high socialist, artistic, communistic, literary quota.  & with the most interesting and I believe inteligent [sic] geographical unit in New York

letterhead  F. VERNON LAMSON   4317 CAROLIN STREET  SUNNYSIDE,  LONG ISLAND CITY
We have about sixty good artists - not very successful for he most part - dancers  poets -- about a hundred or more writers etc  -  several hundred socialists  - ? communists -- plumbers bookeepers doctors lawers [sic] teachers nondescripts and people like ourselves.  All reasonably poor and with much more than the average amount of intelegence [sic] .

   There are many community activities of every kind in most of which we take no part.  We have what is known as the Forum.  One month we settle the negro problem by bringing in a few negroes and shaking hands with them.  They talk of the negro and labor, culture and other things than we have a fine free for all debate.   The following month we do the same with birth controll [sic]  or something else   There is so much variation of opinion and so much latitude to express it that

it really is quite a bit of fun.

   Do you read the Scrips Howard Press.   The World a fine old paper went all to hell here last month it been going for a long time.  Scripps took it over combined it with the Telegram and now New York has one real gawd damned good newspaper.
   Its getting late - this letter is growing too long and I fear I havent said anything and said it poorly.  Its much easier to talk than write.  Think Ill take a drink and go bed.
  Hope to see you before too many months pass.  Things here are pretty lousy now and those allegedly in the know say the really big smash comes next month.  Heres hoping it leaves us with our chins still out

F. Vernon

in pencil in top margin  Howard Swensen

Nov 8  1946
Dear Jack

   Well its good to hear from you.  Some time since I was in Chicago, expect to be in the nineteen to a ceramic meeting its in the evening.  Will call you if I am in.
   Been busy working also trying to get a start with some ceramic figures, built a kiln and just received some clay.
   Well Judys back guess he had a lot to say where was he in the pacific, Would have like to see him but guess hes a bit hurt and sore at me, well if he to recite next month let me know the date may come in and we three could get together.
   Well Jack your book I sent to Morgantown is getting in many hands among teachers  Elizabeth has pass along to some color teacher there too.  But thats not bring the sales up.
   I don't like the strikes and racial up evil [sic] to night heard the town meeting on the Jewish question British and Arabs and the British fear of Allah that cause the White paper from years ago from the umbrella man much like Munich pack and can the situation be ever settle.

Jews are the scrap [sic] goats and thats what keeps them on top in many ways.  British will not give in because of India and the Empire would be at stakes religion for profit to many Mohammedans under their wing.

   Had a letter from Jack was going to see what the wages on some liners guess hes thinking of falling out to sea, said Dee was out of service had his old job back and they are living in Virginia Jack said he see them a couple of times a week.  Hes down in dumps guess a lot of service men are the same as they come out of service the big shots that made the money are offering them less pay or strike breaking offers.
   Will guess I'll close hoping to hear from you soon, if you see Judy tell him I send my rigards [sic] and wish him Luck.

With best regards
?Sved?

The discarded slides I am sending are mostly my goofs on daylilies.  That also goes for other subjects.

  The dogs are the two I kept from an assortment of 8 mutts that I helped into the world.  4 different  sets of identical twins.   Dash I thought was dead when I got him out of the sack but while I was first aiding his sister he crawled over my toe and barked at me.  Dotsy Doodle was a cute baby and needed me.  The others Frotzy, The Badger, Bob, Honey, the Angel and Blackie were wonderful dogs that I found good homes for.  They were abandoned by their mother and my unpleasant neighbors.
   They are truly  amazing dogs and probably have every kind of dog blood that exists.  the best and most intelligent bastards I ever met.
   Beekman Arms is the oldest hotel in this country - 1700 AD - I go there once a month to eat.  Bargain price
   Those nearby are pretty much what I see from here.  If you can project them or even see them some other way I will send more of my leftovers.
   Pink Charm is the one I am trying to hybridize beacause [sic] it had amazing 4 petaled bloom.  I cannot develop it but it's fun trying particularly on very tall and good night bloomers.  
    As soon as I have time and the spark I need I will try to write the story about the Angel to please my memory and commemorate her.  She was a lovely kid.
   Now I must go to work.

handwritten note following typed message  All pix including me are done that way  Dys are 14 inches to 7 feet tall - May to November - most sizes and colors.  Cost 50₵ to $500.00 per plant that takes 2 year to grow from a finger-sized single.  New ones usually $15 to $50 a plant.  My most reckless purchase $3.00 but accidentally I got 50% of the best so far.

[in pencil in top margin]   Lamson, Vernon  [1955]
greeting card  Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year   written in red above greeting:  1955  signed:  Rita & Vernon Lamson
Dear Jack
This has been a helluva year due mostly to some plumbing repairs last Spring  Feel better now  Hope to see you one of these days with a chance to talk
The Surde
Will try to write soon

3

  This fancy paper is too narrow and I am not used to Rita's portable.
  Being married is not an easy job when you are not used to it.   I got me the only girl I was ever in love with and I don't have to waste words telling you about her because you can see very clearly.  But there isn't any easy way to bring order out of the chaos of things.  We are doing things as much as we can when we can to make the schoolhouse over into what we want.  But there is little time and little money.  We did a lot last summer but there is still so damn much to be done.
  We have to live with Rita's mother near the northern most border of the city -- a long bus and subway ride away from our jobs.  The old girl has passed 70 and I suspect is far stronger than her daughter and healthier.  I get along with her as well as I do with anybody but she is hard on Rita.   We are hanging onto my old apartment on 53rd but we are only able to use it as a resting place to catch our breath before the long haul home.
   Between the job, the subway, sleep and many duties and distractions we are not finding too much time to live.  The few friends we have here, we seldom see and as you know we never find time to write to anybody.
   I have a large pocketful of letters now that I would like to answer.  It's Sunday but there is a big hole in it already.  Maybe I beter [sic] turn to some other worthy, patient and long suffering friends and surpise [sic] hell out of them.
  Our very best to you both and may our trails all cross again sometime soon.

the Surde    [pencil in left margin:  V. Lamson]
[handwritten note at end of typed letter]   Can you tell me a good book to refresh myself on how to present stuff for publication etc etc  Its been many years since I tried and I didnt know much then

[penciled notes in top margin]   Xmas    1958       Lamson, Vernon
Dear Jack and Gladys

  We so much enjoyed our last visit with you that we hope to make it as soon as we can.
   Sorry to hear that this year has been tough for you.
  Rita has had it worse than any of the previous 49.
  I fell and busted my square Swedish skull in July and wasnt supposed to live

2
but I got through in a couple of months and enjoyed part of my longest vacation  Rita had it much harder than I did.

  Since then my ulcers, stomach hernia low blood pressure, lost weight etc were harder on her than on me
  Then to top things off, she lost her mother a little more than a week ago.

3
It looks like we are now coming out of the woods.  We are bloody but not unbowed and as soon as the doctor lets me, I hope we can drink some ale together
Our very best
Rita & Surde
PS If I had drunk enough ale I wouldnt have cracked my skull  But  one way or another I am going to continue living in this foolish world, sober or otherwise.  You do the same.

[pencil in top margin]  Lamson, Vernon & Louise
Note new address No POB
F. Vernon Lamson
Kensington Court C3
Hendersonville, NC  28739
27 Nov  1977
Dear Jack and Gladys

   I have been trying to write you a letter for very many months but I have been so fogged up with medicine to keep me breathing that I was unable to do anything much else     Also my hernias started fighting my emphesema [sic] and it has been a very rough year up to now.
   Like Judy Kapshenk I seemed to be headed for the junk yard   However with the help of seven doctors I went in for repairs   Spent two weeks recovering from my patched up transmission and my carburator [sic] is working better than it has for five or more years.  But I damn near died of pneumonia before I came home   To top things off I had my left ear rebuilt by having an enlarged skin cancer removed by dry ice so it is all wrapped up in gauze and tape that has to be changed every 24 hours.  It seems to be mending well so that I wont look like a broken down prize fighter.  Anyway it is no good for hearing 
   Hope and trust that you are aging happy and healthy and Gladys likewise.  Lu has a few mixed up aches and pains but she keeps doing too many things at high speed and I've stopped trying to slow her down

Outside of that we are doing fine and enjoy living in this wonderful part of the world watching the rest of it going rapidly to hell.
   Hope and wish we could get together and reconsider our assorted lives   I believe that we still think very much alike   As soon as winter is over we hope you can spend some time with us here   We can give you a large bedroom with bath and wall to wall carpeting and drive through the amazing Smokeys and have a few night caps of aged corn juice before bed time
   I have at least a bushel of undone bills to pay taxes and unanswered letters from my favorite senior citizen frends. [sic]  From now on I think I will give up Christmas cards and do a few letters like this instead

Our very best to you both 
Vern & Louise
Please send me your phone number it is much easier and perhaps a better way to communicate than expensive mail
Ours is 704-692 5340

Sunday 19th of Dec 1983
Dear Conroys

   Time goes bye so damn fast I am always at least a week or two behind every thing I try to do which is not very much.
   After 60 years of driving without a mark on my license I gave up and sold my car   Now I have to walk and that isnt very far as I can only go a few yards before taking a breath
   Like A E Housman said 

The sun is up and so am I

  To wash and dress and eat and drink

And look at things and talk and think

  And work and God knows why

I get up before the sun does and wait for it to set but everything is down hill

This is an Alice in Wonderland world we live in  But I want to be here when it all goes to Hell with a big Bang
   If we could only live our lives backward
   Wish we can meet again some day   We have spent some of the most interesting hours I can remember as though it happened yesterday.  I dont want to go anywhere    I want to spend Eternity right here in North Carolina or sit on a cloud with you with plenty of time to talk things over.

Sincerely
The Surde
Merry Xmas and Happy New Year   Will tost [sic] you both with my two drinks
[[IMAGE:  seal   SAVE THE SEALS   GREENPEACE

Greeting card:  Best Wishes for the Holidays and Happiness throughout the New Year  signed:  Lillian Lange
[[in pencil in top margin:  Lange, Lillian  [1977]  ]]
Dear Jack & Gladys:

  Will write to you after holidays and let you know all I know about Rose death.   She became very ill and her Dr. sent her to St. Alexis Hospital.  She was there 3 weeks & sent home and then back again.  There were times she seemed to be in a Coma and couldnt talk & would squeeze my hand.  My brother & I talked to her at the hospital she didnt talk & my brother wanted her in a nursing home I said no as I will take her home and hire a nurse and she squeezed my hand so she heard what we said.   Went to see her every visiting hrs. and she always was strong and was so surprised when they called us and said for us to come as she was dead.   I am sure she didnt get proper care at that hospital but it is too late now to think & my girl friend is a nurse and said she was dying when she would gurgle in her throat.  They should of called us before she died so we could be with her.  I left Calif. because she was lonely in N.Y. & went there & lived with her till the family wanted us in Cleveland & came after us.  I miss her.

Lillian Lange

[in pencil in top margin]  Larsen, Eileen
July 25, 1976
Dear Jack.

   You and Gladys have my utmost sympathy.   I am sure you know that Erling and I suffered the tragic loss of a beautiful and talented daughter back in 1960 - a car accident - She was four days away from her 22nd birthday.  She also was a writer of promise.
    Our son and other daughter and their families are coming to see me this week.  I hope to have lots of time to talk about many things with them   One is to find out if Eric, who is writing and publishing is interested in doing something with Erling's works - both published and unpublished.  If he isn't then I think I'l see if I can find someone else who is - or, perhaps, even have a stab at it myself -
   I hope you are back to work on your autobiography - The world needs it.
   I know a bit of how y ou feel

about being "the last leaf on the bough."  I started delving into family trees when I realized our daughter Bonghild's three boys have only underlined: one grandparent living [underlined: me]]!  When their mother was born there were three great-grandmas, two grandmas and a grandpa all living in Northfield - My grandsons' paternal grandparents are also gone - strange as the eldest boy is only 11.

   I hope you and Gladys are feeling better and are physically well.  I know a part of you will never stop grieving and being lonesome but it has to become a way of life, just as death underlined: is a part of life and living.  Loving makes the loss harder - but I would underlined:  never not have loved as I have and do.  And I am sure neither of you would have either.

All best.
Eileen

in pencil in right margin:  Larsen, Eileen
April  5, 1976
Dear Jack Conroy -

   Erling and I didn't send Christmas cards this year as we went off to see our Kinder   We planned in lieu of cards to do latish New Year's letters when we returned mid-January.  But as I find your welcome and newsy card among the unanswered pile, I fear Erling didn't get to write you - so I must do it for him - as he counted you among his honored friends
   After a long seige [sic] with emphysema, Erling died

on the 8th of March - He went by ambulance to our local hospital one month ago tonight.  He made a nobel [sic] effort to get over this attack but his heart couldn't stand it any longer - so now he is at peace.

   Of course I am very lonely but I do not pity myself for I was among the very fortunate to have lived with so good a man for so many, many years -
   I hope your work continues to go well.  I'd like to tell you that double underlined: I  feel you underlined: have earned that Doctor of Humane Letters - as I am sure Erling would, too.
   Thank you for your good card and news - both Erling and I enjoyed it.
   Best wishes to you and Gladys.

Sincerely
Eileen Larsen

letterhead  The Carleton Miscellany   Carleton College, Northfield, Minnesota
Oct 31, 1964
Dear Jack -

   Thanks for your essay, which of course we shall use.  I don't think the symposium will add up to a great deal, or make any real answers, but we do have I think a number of interesting pieces in it.  And we are grateful to you for your help.  If we had a years' time and some money I think we could pursue the various lead we have & make a good book out of it all.   Meanwhile, we have what we have.
  I'm delighted that you had a good summer.  We stayed at home except for a few weeks drive into the Adirondacks.
  I have put your underlined:  Disinherited on the list for my course in 20th Century Fiction.  I don't know how large the registration will be, but it will I suppose be something - & I look forward to seeing what these 60's students make of you.
 Again, many thanks.
And underlined:  all good wishes, 

Erling

letterhead   The Carleton Miscellany   CARLETON COLLEGE, NORTHFIELD, MINNESOTA
1/31/65
Dear Jack -

   I told you I would use your underlined:  Disinherited in my novel course - and I am.  Now I read in one of the reviews of the reprint that you rewrote parts of it for the H&W edition.  I don't have easy access to the first edition, so write to ask you if it is true that you did rewrite.
   This is not very important, but I would be interested in trying to check this out.  Besides, you may be sure those students are going to ask me.   And I'd like to give them an honest, true, answer.

Best,
Erling

letterhead
letterhead   THE CARLETON Miscellany   CARLETON COLLEGE, NORTHFIELD, MINNESOTA
4 Jan '67
Dear Jack -

  It was good to hear from you.  I sent the 30's on to Guggenheim with a note explaining why.  I hope you make it.
  And thanks for the Kalan letter, which I return.  I may get nervy enough to intrude on him one day.  

All good wishes,
Yrs.
Erling

letterhead   The Carleton Miscellany   CARLETON COLLEGE, NORTHFIELD, MINNESOTA  55057
20 May 1969
Dear Jack,

    It was good to hear from you and the sallet and the tracts and all.  And I'm glad you made the Yukon trip.  did you meet our poet and reviewer, J. D. O'Hara?  I'd be curious to know what manner of man he is.
   I am much interest in the H. H. Lewis proposal.  And I would indeed  like to get Ben Hagglund to write more for us.  I too thought his TRIP one of the great things we've been able to print.
    But before I write to him I'd like to know more about what you've done for underlined:  December.   It wouldn't make sense for Ben to duplicate or repeat what you've already said.  What I hope will happen is that you have a critical piece on his verse and Ben could then do the biographical kind of reminiscence.  Is this possible?
  I have another matter on hand too.  In the fall of 1970 I am going to be giving a seminar here on the little magazines of the 20's and 30's.  It comes under "American Studies," which have a budget for visiting dignitaries.  Would you be willing to come up here for a couple of days?  It would involve talking to the class, fifteen kids, for a couple of hours, going to a cocktail or something like that, maybe visiting a few other classes and also having some kind of meeting informally with students interested but not in the seminar.   I have so far thought of you and Ben Botkin and maybe Ben Hagglund.  I want to stay away from the hotshots like Rahv.  I am not sure how much the thing pays but it does include fare and perhaps a couple hundred bucks.  If you are interested I shall begin enquiries as to exact amounts.  I hope you say yes.  We can put you up in a fairly posh guest room on the campus and see that your are fed.  Can't promise hawg jawz, sorry to say.
  Let me know at your convenience about these two things.   The Lewis.  The Northfield visit.
  Meanwhile and always, all the best to you all.

Yrs.
Erling
handwritten note at end   - Would Joe Kalan work in a situation like this?
handwritten note in left margin  We can't figure dates until the College prints its schedule.   But we could settle on a month & maybe even a week.   In the, say, second week October.  Something like that.

letterhead  CARLETON COLLEGE, NORTHFIELD, MINNESOTA 55057   DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH

Dear Jack,

   We are expecting you in a couple of weeks - to arrive on Oct 13, if that's still OK with you.
    Please let us know fairly soon about time of arrival & where so that we can arrange meeting & transport.
   We all look forward to seeing you.

Best,
Erling

Mr. Jack Conroy,
701 Fisk Ave.

Dec.  12, 1949
Dear Jack:
Almost a sixth of a lifetime since I shuffled the time sheets together and made off for Nw York to make good.  During that time I worked five commercial jobs; traveled 115,000 miles as sound and radar man on a destroyer; have spent 28 months in four hospitals, was operated on once with three more and 18 more months to come and go.

  One way or another we put in our time and are ready for the redeemer whether there is anyone to redeem us or not.
  Passed through Chicago last February on my way here from Phoenix where I had gone to rest for the Winter.  I was slipping fast and only went where I could get fed and rest.  Saw several of the boys and girls.  Chicago did not depress me, although I feel better around these parts

3
the month.  The new calendar is the schedule of operations.  Last one was in June  I should go down again in January  Another one perhaps in June.  Another one perhaps in January.  Getting kind of dull, huhhh?  With luck I should be walking around half dead by Summer, 1951.  But most persons have been half dead all their lives.  This is one way to get even!


Thanks for the book.  I read it now and then.  That is the way to enjoy it.
Let me hear from you, what you are doing, your plans.  Letters are good therapy.  Somehow you have to keep busy in here, schedule things to do.  My very best

2.
Sam Ross told me you were working in and "intellectual sweat shop," that  you had lost weight, were back with the wife and kids.  That was more than a year ago.  Gert Gunter told me you were over this way for a while looking something up.
change from blue to green ink
Christmas
Sometimes weeks pass between my beginnings and endings.  
I received your card.  I hope you have a happy holiday too.
This life of lying it out is quite an ordeal:  necessity gives over to habit, then rationalization, then some kind of adequate adjustment - or else.  The first six months are the hardest.  Then a kind of timelessness.  Your calendar enters into it only by pay days, every first of

IMAGE - greeting card  The United Nations photographed and contributed by Gottscho-Schleisner for the benefit of UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund.
red because too many copies had been returned.  DS&P, as you may know, has been absorbed by Meredith Publishing Co. and I don't know how my work will fare from now on.  Anyway, at last report 4000 of the 5000 first printing have been sold.  Thanks for all your kind words on behalf of my book.  (I too had a brief note from Fagin.)  I'm waiting to be plagiarized but haven't been lucky! 

  Thanks for the enclosures.  Someday I'll make it to Chicago, I hope.

Sincerely,
Ray M  Lawless

in pencil in top margin Lawless, Ray
24 Dec. 1961
Dear Jack -

  A severe illness grounded (or underlined: bedded ) me for about six weeks last spring, but I'm fairly fit again.  Had hoped to go to Quebec, via Chicago, during the summer but decided it would be too strenuous.  We wanted to attend the International Folk Music Council doings in Q. but have been nowhere, not even to the Ozarks for the October folk festival.  Just now we are right in the middle of a prairie blizzard, and I'm content to sit by the fire.
  The book is doing modestly well - but only mildly.  At last royalty reporting time (Oct. 1) I was in the

Greeting card  greeting card  ?Chinese characters?SEASON'S GREETINGS     С НОВьІМ ГОДОМ    MEILLEURS VOEUX    FELIZ AÑO NUEVO
Dec. 20, 1965
Dear Jack,

  As you see by the address, we have moved.   Our suburban house and half-acre got to be too much work, and we sold out.  We are closer in to many things now, which makes the driving crossed out:  problem a lesser problem.  My health has been precarious all year, though  I have managed to keep at my teaching  job.  Our Junior College is in a transition stage - from a local district school to an area-wide metropolitan college.  New buildings and campus are in the making, but slowly.  In the meantime, everything is hectic.
  Glad to know of your comings and goings, your trip abroad, also about Win S.  If you move to Moberly, perhaps we can see one another.  We knew about Mary Fagin's death, but did not know NBF had remarried.  Greeting to you both.

Ray & Hazel

RAY M. LAWLESS
900 East 83rd Terrace
Kansas City, Mo. 64131
June 23, 1967
Dear Jack,

  Your recent card has bestirred me to write you, but my health is rather precarious these days, and I am not up to doing much of anything.  This note, however, is not designed to recite my woes.
  On June 5 I retired from teaching, after 35 years in Jr. College crossed out: work here in K.C. and 11 years elsewhere.  More and more the futility of teaching has weighed on me, but we have made some wonderful friends, and I have had, I suppose, more than my share of brilliant students.  And of course the folksong crossed out:  business activity has been an outlet.  (Seems to me I'm not writing what I intended to at all!)
  Warren French's brilliant review of Studs Terkel's underlined:  Division Street: America ought to engender some serious thinking - I hope it will.  I haven't read the book yet, but hope to get at it sometime this summer.  That's another thing:  there are so many books I want to read, I'll never get them done.  Warren French came over to the English dept. reception for me (card enclosed), and I got acquainted with him then.  I will say the Eng. Dept. laid themselves out for me.  The are all (well, underlined: most of them) my good friends.   The Terkel review prodded me

to dig out Win Straake's record underlined:  Americana. and what a remarkable job he does on those folksongs - none better in my small collection.  Have wished these seven years that I could get up to Chicago and meet with you and Studs and Win - but it never came about.  I've been eternally grateful for your favorable review.  (My second edition moves along OK - but the whole business needs doing again.  Someone else will have to do it.)

  Now, to  your card.   We do hope you can get down to K.C.  We'll be at home most of the summer, and I do want to see you.  Give us a ring and I hope we can get together.
  We heard from Fagin recently.  His retirement years have been most fortunate, it seems to me.  Though crossed out:  I've se  we've seen him very little since that summer of 1930 in Vermillion, S.D. (we both taught there that summer), I have considered him one of my best friends.  He has, I believe, sent me a copy of every book and article he has written.
  That's all for now.  Come see us, both of you.

Ray M L

postcard
30 July 1967
Dear Jack, I've just read your review in today's underline: Star and am much interested in your comments.  M U is really on the move in this area. The comment about you, before your essay begins, ought to be a good boost for underline: The Disinherited. I've hoped I'd see you in K.C someday. Now that I'm retired, I'm busier than ever, underline: it seems, but not too busy for friends. Among my books and papers, class notes, etc. I'm carrying out my own little slum clearance project (I need a small federal grant!). Just now I'm working on an article which I hope the underline: Star will use - Carl Sandburg as a ballad singer. Greetings to you both, Ray + Hazel
